titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Otis M. Smith Papers, 1949-1993
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
David Wasserman

did.abstract: Attorney, Michigan state official, justice of the Michigan Supreme Court, 1961-1966, member of the University of Michigan Board of Regents, 1967-1971, general counsel and vice president of the General Motors Corporation. Series consist of Personal which includes biographical information and photographs; Speeches (1963-1992); Michigan Public Service Commission files (1957-1959); Auditor General files (1959-1961); General Motors Corporation files (1967-1969); University of Michigan Board of Regents files (1967-1971) which documents in part the Black Action Movement, the controversy over the role of R.O.T.C., and other issues involving the administration of the university; campaign files (1966-1968); and Michigan Supreme Court files (1961-1966).

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection (Donor No. 8279) was donated by the Otis Smith estate in October, 1994.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Otis M. Smith Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Otis M. Smith was born in Memphis, Tennessee, on February 20, 1922. He received his undergraduate education at Fisk University and Syracuse University. He received his law degree in 1950 from the Catholic University of America, Washington D.C. Over the course of his legal career he was admitted to practice in Michigan, the District of Columbia and the United States Supreme Court.

Otis M. Smith started his legal career as an assistant prosecutor in Flint, Michigan in 1950. He was appointed chairman of the Public Service Commission by Governor G. Mennen Williams in 1957. In 1959 Smith was appointed state auditor general of Michigan, a post to which he was subsequently elected in 1960. In 1961, he was named a justice of the Supreme Court of the State of Michigan, a post to which he was subsequently elected in 1962. Throughout his public service career, Smith was well known as one of the United States' highest ranking African-American elected or appointed officials.
Smith lost his bid for reelection to the State Supreme Court of the State of Michigan in 1966. In 1967 Smith accepted an appointment with the legal division of General Motors Corporation.

In 1967 Smith was named by Governor George Romney to the University of Michigan Board of Regents. Smith served out the remainder of Allen R. Sorenson's elected term but chose not to run for reelection in 1971. Smith's tenure as a university regent was laced with numerous incidences of campus unrest and disharmony within the university community.

Smith was named Associate General Counsel and Vice President of General Motors Corporation in 1974. He was elected to the post of General Counsel in 1977 by the GM Board of Directors, thus becoming one of the highest ranking African-Americans in corporate America. Smith retired from General Motors Corporation on 1 April, 1984 and went on to serve as counsel to the Detroit, Michigan law firm of Lewis, White and Clay.
Otis Smith died 29 June 1994 after a four year bout with prostate cancer at the age of 72.

scopecontent.p: The Otis M. Smith papers contains speeches, correspondence, examples of work produced in various offices, and photographs. This collection documents the career of a dedicated public servant and the many posts he held.

The Otis M. Smith papers are divided into eight series: Personal, Speeches, Michigan Public Service Commission Papers, Auditor General Papers, General Motors Papers, Regent Papers, Campaign Files and Supreme Court Papers.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: Michigan. Office of the Auditor General.
University of Michigan. Board of Regents.
United States. Army. Reserve Officers' Training Corps.

scopecontent.p: Personal (4 folders; 1949-1993) includes biographical information and photographs of Otis M. Smith in a variety of poses and professional settings, as well as photos of contemporaries. The series also includes materials accumulated by Smith after his retirement from General Motors Corporation in 1984.

Portraits; photos of Smith with William O. Douglas and with John F. Kennedy; photo of G. Mennen Williams with Harry Truman, and of Thurgood Marshall and Wade McCree; also photos of Smith campaigning and with other judges and attorneys in various group settings.

odd.p: (includes photo of G. Mennen Williams and Harry S. Truman and photo of Thurgood Marshall)

scopecontent.p: Speeches (.7 linear feet; 1963-1992) documents Otis M. Smith's career as a highly respected public servant, member of the legal community, and member of the corporate business world. A large percentage of the speeches are indexed and arranged in chronological order; the index can be found in the folder preceding the indexed speeches. Non-indexed speeches are also arranged chronologically and largely originate from the years following Smith's retirement from General Motors Corporation in 1984.

Michigan Public Service Commission Papers (4 folders; 1957-1959) documents Smith's tenure as chairman of the Michigan Public Service Commission. This series contains correspondence regarding Smith's appointment as chairman as well as correspondence originating from the office. This series also contains a press release authored by Smith detailing the commission and its functions. The folders are arranged alphabetically.

Auditor General Papers (7 folders; 1959-1961) documents the workings of the governmental position held by Smith prior to his appointment to the State Supreme Court of Michigan. This series contains correspondence and clippings relating the Auditor General's office. This series also contains examples of the office's work in the form of a survey conducted by Smith and samples of staff audit work. The folders are arranged alphabetically.

General Motors Papers (3 folders; 1967-1969) includes non-regent related materials originating from Smith's General Motors office. The majority of Smith's General Motors papers were removed prior to the donation of Smith's papers. The correspondence and other materials presented in this series document Smith's many roles outside his corporate job as a respected citizen and former member of the political realm. The folders are arranged alphabetically.

Regent Papers (1.1 linear feet; 1967-1971) documents Smith's years as a member of the University of Michigan Board of Regents. Smith's regent papers cover a wide range of issues that serve to document the university when it was inundated with student unrest and the political climate of the United States in the late 1960s. Included in this series are folders on the following: Black Action Movement (B.A.M.), Reserve Officer Training Corps (R.O.T.C.), citizen dissatisfaction with the role of the regents and the role of the university president, The Michigan Daily, and admissions of students. The folders in this series are arranged alphabetically and often retain Smith's original folder headings. Some folders contain notes written by Smith regarding their content.

did.unittitle: Association of Governing Boards of Universities and Colleges 1969
Martin Luther King Memorial Scholarship Fund 1968-1970
Paul G. Goebel Endowed Chair Committee 1967

scopecontent.p: Campaign Files (.5 linear feet; 1966-1968) documents various political campaigns in the state of Michigan, notably Smith's 1962 successful and 1966 unsuccessful re-election campaigns for the State Supreme Court of Michigan. This series also documents Smith's involvement in Hubert Humphrey's 1968 Presidential bid. The folders are arranged chronologically.

Supreme Court Papers (1 linear foot; 1961-1990) documents Smith's tenure as a justice of the State Supreme Court of Michigan. Included are opinions/window matters authored by Smith on cases presented to the court, a folder of opinions Smith deemed his "best cases," court memorandums authored by Smith, folders on specific court matters, and a survey conducted by the court. The folders in this series are arranged alphabetically and are closed to researchers until the death of all of the members of the court who served with Smith.
